query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Godi, Fiorenza, poi che se’ sì grande 2 che per mare e per terra batti l’ali, 3 e per lo ’nferno tuo nome si spande!
4 Tra li ladron trovai cinque cotali 5 tuoi cittadini onde mi ven vergogna, 6 e tu in grande orranza non ne sali.
query.result:
1 Rejoice, Florence, since you are so great 2 that over sea and land you beat the wings, 3 and through your hell your name spreads!
4 Among the thieves I found five such ones 5 your citizens for whom I feel shame, 6 and you do not rise in great esteem because of them.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
7 Ma se presso al mattin del ver si sogna, 8 tu sentirai, di qua da picciol tempo, 9 di quel che Prato, non ch’altri, t’agogna.
query.result: 7 But if near the morning one dreams of truth, 8 you will hear, from here in a short time, 9 of what Prato, not others, concerns you.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 E se già fosse, non saria per tempo. 11 Così foss’ ei, da che pur esser dee! 12 ché più mi graverà, com’ più m’attempo.
query.result: 10 And if it already were, it would not be too soon. 11 Thus let him be, since he must be! 12 because it will weigh on me more, the more it delays.

13 We departed, and up the stairs 14 that he had made rough to descend before, 15 my duke ascended and drew me;
16 and continuing the solitary way, 17 among the splinters and the rocks of the cliff 18 the foot without the hand does not proceed.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 Allor mi dolsi, e ora mi ridoglio 20 quando drizzo la mente a ciò ch’io vidi, 21 e più lo ’ngegno affreno ch’i’ non soglio,
22 perché non corra che virtù nol guidi; 23 sì che, se stella bona o miglior cosa 24 m’ha dato ’l ben, ch’io stessi nol m’invidi.
query.result:
19 Then I grieved, and now I regret 20 when I raise my mind to what I saw, 21 and I rein in my intellect more than I am accustomed,
22 because it does not run if virtue does not guide it; 23 so that, if a good star or better thing 24 has given me the good, I did not envy it to myself.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Quante ’l villan ch’al poggio si riposa, 26 nel tempo che colui che ’l mondo schiara 27 la faccia sua a noi tien meno ascosa,
28 come la mosca cede a la zanzara, 29 vede lucciole giù per la vallea, 30 forse colà dov’ e’ vendemmia e ara:
31 di tante fiamme tutta risplendea 32 l’ottava bolgia, sì com’ io m’accorsi 33 tosto che fui là ’ve ’l fondo parea.
query.result:
25 How many a peasant who rests on the hill, 26 in the time that he who illuminates the world 27 holds his face less hidden from us,
28 as the fly yields to the mosquito, 29 sees fireflies down through the valley, 30 perhaps where there is vintage and plowing:
31 by so many flames all shone 32 the eighth bolgia, as I realized 33 quickly that I was where the bottom appeared.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 E qual colui che si vengiò con li orsi 35 vide ’l carro d’Elia al dipartire, 36 quando i cavalli al cielo erti levorsi,
37 che nol potea sì con li occhi seguire, 38 ch’el vedesse altro che la fiamma sola, 39 sì come nuvoletta, in sù salire:
40 tal si move ciascuna per la gola 41 del fosso, ché nessuna mostra ’l furto, 42 e ogne fiamma un peccatore invola.
query.result:
34 And as he who avenged himself with the bears 35 saw Elijah’s chariot at its departure, 36 when the horses lifted themselves erect to the sky,
37 that he could not follow it so with his eyes, 38 that he saw anything other than the flame alone, 39 just as a little cloud, ascending on high:
40 thus each one moves through the throat 41 of the ditch, because none shows the theft, 42 and each flame carries a sinner away.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
43 Io stava sovra ’l ponte a veder surto, 44 sì che s’io non avessi un ronchion preso, 45 caduto sarei giù sanz’ esser urto.
query.result: 43 I was standing on the bridge to see rising, 44 so that if I hadn’t taken a hooked grappling iron, 45 I would have fallen down without being struck.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 E ’l duca che mi vide tanto atteso, 47 disse: «Dentro dai fuochi son li spirti; 48 catun si fascia di quel ch’elli è inceso».

Please translate each line literally into English.
49 «Maestro mio», rispuos’ io, «per udirti 50 son io più certo; ma già m’era avviso 51 che così fosse, e già voleva dirti:
52 chi è ’n quel foco che vien sì diviso 53 di sopra, che par surger de la pira 54 dov’ Eteòcle col fratel fu miso?».
query.result:
49 “My master,” I responded, “to hear you 50 I am more certain; but already it was known to me 51 that thus it was, and already I wanted to tell you:
52 Who is in that fire that comes so divided 53 from above, that it seems to rise from the pyre 54 where Eteocles with his brother was placed?”

55 He responded to me: “There within they suffer 56 Ulysses and Diomedes, and thus together 57 to the vengeance they go as to the wrath;
58 and within from their flame one groans 59 about the ambush of the horse that made the gate 60 from which came forth the noble seed of the Romans.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Piangevisi entro l’arte per che, morta, 62 Deïdamìa ancor si duol d’Achille, 63 e del Palladio pena vi si porta».
query.result: 61 There one weeps within the art for which, dead, 62 Deidamia still grieves for Achilles, 63 and of the Palladium pain is carried there.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 «S’ei posson dentro da quelle faville 65 parlar», diss’ io, «maestro, assai ten priego 66 e ripriego, che ’l priego vaglia mille,
67 che non mi facci de l’attender niego 68 fin che la fiamma cornuta qua vegna; 69 vedi che del disio ver’ lei mi piego!».
query.result:
64 “If they can from those sparks 65 speak,” I said, “master, I very much beg 66 and re-beg, that the begging may be worth a thousand,
67 that they do not make me deny 68 waiting until the horned flame comes here; 69 see that with the desire I bend towards her!”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
70 Ed elli a me: «La tua preghiera è degna 71 di molta loda, e io però l’accetto; 72 ma fa che la tua lingua si sostegna.

Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Lascia parlare a me, ch’i’ ho concetto 74 ciò che tu vuoi; ch’ei sarebbero schivi, 75 perch’ e’ fuor greci, forse del tuo detto».
query.result: 73 Leave speaking to me, for I have understood 74 what you want; because they would be reluctant, 75 because they are Greeks, perhaps of your saying.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Poi che la fiamma fu venuta quivi 77 dove parve al mio duca tempo e loco, 78 in questa forma lui parlare audivi:
79 «O voi che siete due dentro ad un foco, 80 s’io meritai di voi mentre ch’io vissi, 81 s’io meritai di voi assai o poco
82 quando nel mondo li alti versi scrissi, 83 non vi movete; ma l’un di voi dica 84 dove, per lui, perduto a morir gissi».
query.result:
76 After that the flame came there 77 where it seemed to my guide time and place, 78 in this form I heard him speak:
79 “O you who are two within a fire, 80 if I merited from you while I lived, 81 if I merited from you much or little
82 when in the world the high verses I wrote, 83 do not move; but let one of you say 84 where, through him, I lost myself to die.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 Lo maggior corno de la fiamma antica 86 cominciò a crollarsi mormorando, 87 pur come quella cui vento affatica;
88 indi la cima qua e là menando, 89 come fosse la lingua che parlasse, 90 gittò voce di fuori e disse: «Quando
91 mi diparti’ da Circe, che sottrasse 92 me più d’un anno là presso a Gaeta, 93 prima che sì Enëa la nomasse,
94 né dolcezza di figlio, né la pieta 95 del vecchio padre, né ’l debito amore 96 lo qual dovea Penelopè far lieta,
97 vincer potero dentro a me l’ardore 98 ch’i’ ebbi a divenir del mondo esperto 99 e de li vizi umani e del valore;
100 ma misi me per l’alto mare aperto 101 sol con un legno e con quella compagna 102 picciola da la qual non fui diserto.

Please translate each line literally into English.
103 L’un lito e l’altro vidi infin la Spagna, 104 fin nel Morrocco, e l’isola d’i Sardi, 105 e l’altre che quel mare intorno bagna.
query.result: 103 One shore and the other I saw up to Spain, 104 up to Morocco, and the island of the Sardinians, 105 and the others that that sea around bathes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Io e ’ compagni eravam vecchi e tardi 107 quando venimmo a quella foce stretta 108 dov’ Ercule segnò li suoi riguardi
109 acciò che l’uom più oltre non si metta; 110 da la man destra mi lasciai Sibilia, 111 da l’altra già m’avea lasciata Setta.
query.result:
106 I and my companions were old and late 107 when we came to that narrow mouth 108 where Hercules marked his boundaries
109 so that man does not go further; 110 from the right hand I left Sicily, 111 from the other already had left me Ceuta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 “O frati”, dissi “che per cento milia 113 perigli siete giunti a l’occidente, 114 a questa tanto picciola vigilia
115 d’i nostri sensi ch’è del rimanente 116 non vogliate negar l’esperïenza, 117 di retro al sol, del mondo sanza gente.
query.result:
112 “O brothers,” I said, “who for a hundred thousand 113 perils have come to the west, 114 to this so small vigil
115 of our senses that is of the remainder, 116 do not wish to deny the experience, 117 behind the sun, of the world without people.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Considerate la vostra semenza: 119 fatti non foste a viver come bruti, 120 ma per seguir virtute e canoscenza”.
query.result: 118 Consider your origin: 119 you were not made to live like beasts, 120 but to follow virtue and knowledge.

121 My companions I made so eager, 122 with this small speech, on the way, 123 that scarcely afterwards would I have held them back;
124 and we turned our stern in the morning, 125 of the oars we made wings for the mad flight, 126 always gaining from the left side.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Tutte le stelle già de l’altro polo 128 vedea la notte, e ’l nostro tanto basso, 129 che non surgëa fuor del marin suolo.
query.result: 127 All the stars already of the other pole 128 I saw at night, and ours so low, 129 that it did not rise above the marine soil.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Cinque volte racceso e tante casso 131 lo lume era di sotto da la luna, 132 poi che ’ntrati eravam ne l’alto passo,
133 quando n’apparve una montagna, bruna 134 per la distanza, e parvemi alta tanto 135 quanto veduta non avëa alcuna.
query.result:
130 Five times renewed and as many extinguished 131 the light was from beneath the moon, 132 after that we had entered into the high passage,
133 when appeared to us a mountain, dark 134 because of the distance, and seemed to me high as much 135 as I had not seen any.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
136 Noi ci allegrammo, e tosto tornò in pianto; 137 ché de la nova terra un turbo nacque 138 e percosse del legno il primo canto.

Please translate each line literally into English.
139 Tre volte il fé girar con tutte l’acque; 140 a la quarta levar la poppa in suso 141 e la prora ire in giù, com’ altrui piacque,
142 infin che ’l mar fu sovra noi richiuso».
query.result:
139 Three times he made it turn with all the waters; 140 at the fourth he raised the stern upwards 141 and the prow to go down, as it pleased another,
142 until the sea was closed over us.
